addressleaf.section:
Fe
b
20. 88. To the right honorable my very good Lorde, e Lorde high Treasuro
r
of England

Feb
r
20. 88 to My L. Treasuro
r

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589. sti: Rom.
20 Feb. To M
r
Secretary.
Right honorable, and my very good Lord, I presume
that
M
r
Killegrew
hath so acquainted yo
r
L. with
e present state of this government, as I neede not
be troblesome in that behalf, but only signifie, that
it was confuse, when he departed from hens,
and
so it
doth continew, geving very litle hope of a better
state towardes. For all is heere directed by
Holland,
and Holland is caried away by
Barnevelt,
whose
resoluc
on
s are so full of self will, and so opposit
to her
Ma
ties
proceedinges, as there are of
e wisest a-
mong themselves, that feare by his dealing, some
great alteration. For
e hindraunce wherof, I can not
readely propose any one better meanes, then if that
course whiche is held betweene him and
Ortell,
might
be stopped in
England.
For maters heere are so
handled at this present, as in whatsoever cause
e
states g
nr
al
, or they of Holland and
Zeland
have
to deale w
t
her Ma
tie
, they nether propose it before to
e
Councell of state
, nor impart it w
t
her Ma
ties
Lieutenant or Counsaillo
r
, but by Barnevelts di-
rection solicit all by Ortell, and so receave their
dispatche: wherby
e reputation of every action, doth
redound unto him, and her Ma
ties
Lieutenant and
ministers are litle regarded. Howbeit when any
suche requestes, or propositions of theirs, shalbe offered
at home, if it might stand w
t
her Ma
ties
pleasure
in maters
at require no hast, and are belonging
to
e government heere, to putte them of, and refuse
to answear, untill she be advertised from hens, howe
thinges are understoode, no dout it would be a great
meanes to make them use her Ma
ties
servants with
a greater respect, and to thinke themselves lesse stee-
ded by Barnevelt: as also it would maintene cor-
respondence, betweene o
r
actions heere and at home,
and minister meanes to many thinges of easier dispatche.
This being an honest, and a direct way, and benefi-
ciall for her Ma
ties
service, I am bold to referre it
to yo
r
L. consideration. What hath passed
fol.55v
betweene
e states g
n
ral and me about
e articles of
my Instructions, and other like buisnes, I doe not dout
but
M
r
Secretary
will informe yo
r
L. They are very
muche disquieted by reason
e supernumerarie com-
panies are still detened in
e Cautionary townes, w
ch
is
a point
at will hardly stand w
t
e Contract: and
yet it is generally thought, that if they should be once
drawen fourth, we shall nether be able to place them
there againe, and
e townes will be masters of those
that shall remaine. It is given out,
at the
ennemie hath an intention of an enterprise uppon Ber-
ghen and ostend, wherof they are advertised heere from
sundrie places. And yet it may be imagined, that all
is but a scarrecrowe, to make
e Governo
rs
of those
townes more unwilling to spare of their companies
for
e
Portugall
voiage.
S
r
Martin Schincke
hath defeated an Italian company, of whiche
e most
part were slaine, and many taken prisoners. The
captaines coullo
rs
he hath sent to me, for a token to her
Ma
tie
to whome he hath also written to suche purpose
as M
r
Secretary will impart w
t
yo
r
L. The
Ammond of Thule
hath agreed w
t
e states, taken his
oth, and cast downe his fort. My
L. Willughby
who departed hens for England
e 15 of this moneth,
taketh
Gertrudenbergh
in his way, where it is certified
hither, that
e souldiers are fallen into a mutine among
themselves: w
ch
I hope my L. will appeare for
e
time. But
e government there is so popular, and so
voide of discipline, and injurious to all
e Contrey
therabout, as every other day come hither to
e state
newe complaintes against them. They pretend to hold
e towne for her Ma
tie
but considering what people
they are, and howe litle a governo
r
can prevaile
among them, it is greatly to be feared, lest waxing
weary of him, or one of an other, they will make the
most of
e place, and turne to
e ennemie. Heere
w
t
I send yo
r
L. a booke, whiche
e autor himself a
student of
Leiden
hath sent unto me for her Ma
tie
unto
whome it is dedicated. If yo
r
L. shall vouchesafe
e
fol.56r
deliverie, and use a litle mediation, for some smalle
reward, in token of her Hig
nes
acceptation, it wilbe
a great encouragement to
e yonge man, being but
twenty yeres of age, and scarce of 5 yeres study, w
ch
is almost incredible, but
at it is knowen to be true,
as I finde in this contrey many straunge wittes of
e like age, and of as great or greater forwardnes
in learning. It hath bin written hither from
Arnham,
at for certaine
e Bishop of
Maience
,
e Elector,
is maried. Howbeit it is signified w
t
out further
particularitie, and not otherwise c
o
firmed sins.
Ha-
ving nothing els, to signifie from hens, I take my
humble leave. From
e Hage. Fe
b
20. 88.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
There are other letters come newly from
Arnham, whiche c
o
firme
e mariage of the
Elector, and signifie further that the
Bishop of
Liege
is deceased: and that
those of
Collen
of
e religion use
publicke preaching. It is
also written from
Andwerp,
that
e Spaniardes have besett
e
house of
e Jesuites: but I can not yet learne, in what maner, nor
what
e cause is: unles it be for
at, w
ch
I have seene testified
by divers letters, that
e Jesuites preache in many places,
at
e
D of Parma
his toleration of
e Protestants in that contrey
was
e chief cause, for w
ch
God would not prosper
e Spanishe
fleete. Moreover this day
e
K of Navarra
sent hither a
letter of thankes to
e states, for
e two hundred thousand florins w
ch
they promised by
Du Fay
his Embassado
r
, to lend him, for
e Levieng
of forces in
Germany.
He requesteth
e continuance of
at promise,
that way, and to procure
e like from some others, desiring that
their mony may be ready, when the time shall require.
